posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Apologies if frame rate is not how you’d refer to this.  I’m referring to the 20 ms loop rate.

I’m aware of addPeriodic in TimedRobot providing a mechanism to schedule periodic functions at higher and even offset rates.

Here are my questions.

Is it possible to do this at the subsystem level?  Lots of method passes to get from a subsystem up to Robot.java

Is it possible to do this at the subsystem level?  Lots of method passes to get from a subsystem up to Robot.java

Are there any other mechanisms to achieve this provided by WPILib?

Are there any other mechanisms to achieve this provided by WPILib?

Just out of curiousity the CommandScheduler itself cannot be sped up?

Just out of curiousity the CommandScheduler itself cannot be sped up?

As for 3. The command scheduler runs as often as command scheduler.run() is called. That currently happens In robot periodic. If you move this function to a loop that runs faster than 20 Ms then commands and subsystem periodics will run faster.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Now the next question, what can the RIO handle in terms of frame rates.  10 Ms, 1Ms, etc.

I know this invariably depends how many subsystems and commands that the scheduler has.  Just looking for anectdotal, experience based knowledge on this front?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
That depends on several things.  Language, speed of different loops, etc.

I know in LabVIEW in the past we rarely ran loops faster than 10 ms, and slowed down others to keep the CPU utilization below 80%.  We would usually target our sensor-acquisition loops and controll loops, and tried to run them faster than the sensor could physically update.
You should be able to measure this. Run VisualVm to measure how long commandscheduler.run() takes and then set the loop time to that plus a bit more for extra safety.

link_counts.title: Profiling with VisualVM — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

Just out of curiousity the CommandScheduler itself cannot be sped up?

You could, but packets from the driver station are sent at 50 Hz. So all of your triggers that rely on driver station input wouldn’t benefit from running faster than 50 Hz.

Triggers that rely on robot input could benefit, however

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: This could lead to some interesting optimisations with running triggers on different loops

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

Is it possible to do this at the subsystem level? Lots of method passes to get from a subsystem up to Robot.java

You can always just inject the addPeriodic method into the subsystem ctor.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: That was my thought.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: I found a TimedSliceRobot template in the template wizard.  Is there a way that can be modified for CommandBased programming or is its purpose separate

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: on the topic of control frequency, I noticed that the default loop waits on a hardware interrupt, presumably to simplify precise alignment to 50hz.  I’m curious if that alignment really matters?  if your code knows the time, then whatever rate-dependent thing it does can be done correctly at any frequency.  is there a reason not to make the tightest loops just free run?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

inject the addPeriodic method into the subsystem ctor

subsystem.periodic() runs with the CommandScheduler so I think OP is asking if other selected methods within the subsystem can run at a different loop rate.

What Java syntax injects addPeriodic() from within the Robot class into the ctor of any other class to accomplish this?

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Thanks.  I was halfway through implementing that from another source and decided to curry instead.  See updated code

EDIT:  BTW.  I love the new Java Units Library.

I don’t need Supplier’s anymore

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
truher:

is there a reason not to make the tightest loops just free run?

GC in Java limits how much faster than the main loop you can consistently get.  If your loop timing is inconsistent then running it faster tends not to help much.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: hm ok, what I was mostly wondering was why consistency is important at all.  when you say “it tends not to help much,” what do you mean?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: If you’re doing something like PID , consistent loop timing is critical for the integral and derivative terms.  Other mathematical models also are likely to be more stable at fixed rates than widely varying rates.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: If you know the delta t of your loop, it is trivial to compensate for inconsistent loop times. I have no idea how accurate the timestamp functions are or how much overhead that would add though, maybe that’s something you could comment on?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Getting the FPGA timestamp is very low overhead, on the order of 150 nanoseconds, although JNI overhead will add to that.  The FPGA timestamp is 1 microsecond resolution.
